Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A test of the vocal grooming hypothesis in the gelada

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One intriguing hypothesis about the origins of human language is that it emerged as a 'social tool,' facilitating our abilities to maintain relationships with an increasing number of people (the "social grooming hypothesis"). The basic idea is that social grooming (which facilitates a bond with only one individual) is replaced by vocal 'grooming' (which facilitates bonds with several individuals, simultaneously). Indeed, social bonds have adaptive value for both humans and non-human primates. Thus, if vocal contact represents an efficient way to maintain relationships, then selection should favor its development. Despite a great deal of theoretical support, however, the social grooming hypothesis has yet to be tested empirically. Geladas provide an excellent model to test this because they are highly social, exceptionally vocal, and uniquely time-constrained because they must spend much of their day foraging on grass. This research by doctoral student Elizabeth Johnson (University of Michigan), under the supervision of Dr. Jacinta Beehner, will explore the strategies that female geladas employ to maintain their social networks, with a specific emphasis on when vocalizations are used, the responses they elicit, and whether such vocal contact supplements or replaces social grooming when time budgets are particularly strained. By utilizing a combination of methods, including behavioral observation, social network analysis, analysis of 'stress' hormones, and acoustic analysis of recorded vocalization, this research will elucidate one possible route by which human ancestors may have maintained social bonds, allowing for larger groups and greater group cohesion.

Results from this study not only contribute to a better understanding of female gelada social relationships, but also provide a comparative dataset for on-going collaborative projects on closely related species (e.g., anubis and hamadryas baboons). Further, this research extends beyond academia, raising awareness about the study site (the Simien Mountains National Park of Ethiopia, a World Heritage Site in Danger) and the study species, an endemic species to the highlands of Ethiopia with a conservation status labeled as "Threatened" by the IUCN Red List. Finally, this doctoral dissertation research project contributes to the long-term viability of the park by hiring a local field assistant (providing both employment opportunities as well as continuing education for these young adults), working closely with park officials, and providing educational lectures to Ethiopian nationals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Social bonds are critical for both human and non-human primates. The ‘vocal grooming hypothesis’ proposes that, when social time is constrained for whatever reason, vocalizations can serve the same function as grooming for cementing social bonds. However, despite gaining theoretical support, this hypothesis has never been tested empirically. This research will test four non-mutually exclusive hypotheses that relate to the function of primate vocalizations: (1) the spatial cohesion hypothesis, (2) the social bonding hypothesis, and two versions of the vocal grooming hypothesis: (3) the time constraint hypothesis, and (4) the extended network hypothesis. Specifically, this research focused on the context(s) in which females vocalize, the responses calls elicit, and how the acoustic properties of calls vary according to individual identity and context. All research was conducted on a population of geladas living in the Simien Mountains National Park, Ethiopia from Sep 2013-Sep 2014. A combination of methods were used, including (1) behavioral observations, (2) analysis of ‘stress’ hormones, (3) social network analysis, and (4) acoustic analysis of recorded vocalizations.

 

Behavioral observations have demonstrated that, first, female geladas form their closest social bonds with other females who are close relatives and similar in dominance rank (Tinsley Johnson et al. 2014). An analysis of ‘stress’ hormones has revealed that females experience seasonal, as well as social, stressors: specifically, they experience more stress during the cold, wet season and when they live in especially small (1-4 adult females) or large (8+ adult females) units. Tinsley Johnson is now applying social network analysis methods to understand how female geladas manage their social relationships, and why medium-sized units appear to be most beneficial. This work will also help address the questions above on vocal grooming, which is perhaps how females manage their relationships even when time-constrained. Finally, acoustic analyses will be conducted to determine whether individuals do, indeed, produce acoustically distinct calls that carry identifying characteristics. Together, these results provide support for the vocal grooming hypothesis, and, when completed, will give us a better understanding of which of the four hypotheses best describe the use of contact calls in geladas.

 

Broader Impacts

The gelada project is strongly committed to increasing awareness about conservation and scientific research. Geladas are listed as “rare” and SMNP is currently listed as a “World Heritage Site in Danger” (by the IUCN). Recently, Beehner established “Save the Simiens”, a nonprofit dedicated to raising money to aid with conservation efforts in the SMNP. To aid in these efforts, Tinsley Johnson presented educational lectures on gelada behavioral biology and conservation to park rangers and ecotourists at the site in Ethiopia. Additionally, Tinsley Johnson trained biology and ecology experts from the Ethiopian Wildlife Authority on field methods, such as hormone sample collection, and gelada behavior and biology. These young trainees were selected to participate in this program, working closely with the University of Michigan Gelada Research Project, in order to obtain a better understanding of primate behavior. Furthermore, Tinsley Johnson worked closely with a field assistant from a local village, providing valuable training for a future career in science and ecotourism.
